Title: BTS' RM and V Discharged Following South Korean Military Service
Description:
"Please wait just a little longer and we will return with a really cool performance," V told fans and media in Chuncheon City on Tuesday.


													By
												

	Tyler Jenke



	The long-awaited BTS reunion is getting closer to happening, with two more members of the South Korean group completing their mandatory military service.


	On Tuesday (June 10), it was reported that BTS members RM and V were discharged from the South Korean military after completing their required service. The pair's discharge was welcomed by hundreds of their fans (known as members of BTS' ARMY fandom) who had gathered in Chuncheon City to greet the two musicians.





	
	
		
					Related		
	

















	
	
		
					Quincy Jones Remembered by Lucky Daye, Luke James & Miles Caton With Smooth 2025 BET Awards Tribute		
	



	06/09/2025	









	
	
		
					Explore		
	





		Explore	

















	
		
					BTS		
					


See latest videos, charts and news



See latest videos, charts and news



See latest videos, charts and news

See latest videos, charts and news


	‚ÄúTo all the ARMYs who have waited for us in the military, I want to say I am truly, truly grateful,‚Äù V told gathered fans and media. ‚ÄúPlease wait just a little longer and we will return with a really cool performance.‚Äù

	










			Trending on Billboard		







	BTS pressed pause on their work as a group in 2023 in order for its members to fulfill their duties as South Korean men between the ages of 18 and 35 and serve a total of 18 months in the South Korean military. 

	











	Jin and J-Hope were discharged from their service in June and October of 2024, respectively, while Jimin and JungKook are scheduled to be discharged on Wednesday (June 11). Suga was assigned alternative service, and has been operating as a social worker since his service began. His discharge is expected to occur later this month.


	While all members of BTS have released solo projects in the interim, the approaching end of their collective military service has been eagerly anticipated by fans, who are looking forward to the band announcing their official reunion plans.


	‚ÄúI look forward to June when our members will have completed their service,‚Äù J-Hope told Apple Music 1's Zane Lowe last month. ‚ÄúWe will quickly get together and talk about what BTS can do in the future. I think it's going to be a massive energy.‚Äù 


	‚ÄúWhen we're all back together as a group, it's going to have a huge impact, and everybody's going to be watching,‚Äù J-Hope also said to Weverse Magazine in December. ‚ÄúI'm excited to see what it'll feel like when we perform together again. I want to come back in style and say, ‚ÄòThis is us. This is BTS.' I can't speak for everyone, but I can tell you the other members feel the same way.‚Äù

Title: Jonathan Mayers, Bonnaroo Co-Founder, Dies
Description:
The festival pioneer was also a creative force behind Outside Lands and Clusterfest.


													By
												

	Dave Brooks



Jonathan Mayers, co-founder of Superfly Entertainment and the co-creator of iconic festivals including Bonnaroo and Outside Lands, has died. His age and cause of death are unknown at this time.


‚ÄúThis is incredibly tough news for so many of us,‚Äù Red Light Management founder Coran Capshaw told Billboard. ‚ÄúJon was the creative force behind so much of what people experience at Bonnaroo, Outside Lands, and many other events over the years. We're all really going to miss him.‚Äù


	Mayers grew up an hour outside New York City and attended Tulane University in New Orleans, graduating in 1995. He was first introduced to the music business through his work with famed New Orleans venue Tipitina's and the long-running Jazz Fest celebration. He co-founded promotion company Superfly in 1996 with Rick Farman, Richard Goodstone and Kerry Black and staged its first concert during Mardi Gras with the Meters, Maceo Parker and Rebirth Brass Band. In 2002, the four men launched and sold out the first Bonnaroo after discovering the perfect festival site an hour outside of Nashville in Manchester, Tenn. Partnering with promoter Ashley Capps of AC Entertainment, agent Chip Hooper of Paradigm and manager Coran Capshaw of Red Light ‚Äî and securing headliners like Trey Anastasio from Phish and Grateful Dead's Phil Lesh and Bob Weir ‚Äî the men created a 70,000-person festival that would become the blueprint for hundreds of other music festivals across the country.




			Trending on Billboard		







	In 2005, Mayers' Superfly launched Vegoose in Las Vegas with programming at multiplevenues throughout the city. The first festival brought in approximately 37,000 visitors, and Mayers and his team ran the festival for three seasons before opting to shut it down. Mayers would also partner with Another Planet Entertainment in the San Francisco Bay Area in 2008 to launch Outside Lands in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park. In 2017, Mayers led efforts to partner with Viacom and Comedy Central to produce a large-scale indoor/outdoor comedy festival in San Francisco called Clusterfest that included performances by Kevin Hart, Amy Schumer, Jon Stewart and Trevor Noah.


	While working on Clusterfest, Mayers began interfacing with major film and TV rights holders and created a new experience concept allowing fans to ‚Äústep inside‚Äù some of their favorite TV shows on recreated TV sets. Mayers and team licensed rights from shows like Seinfeld, The Office, South Park, Arrested Development, It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia and The Daily Show to create immersive fan experiences visited by hundreds of thousands of fans. For the show Friends, Mayers led efforts to create pop-up experiences in multiple cities, including New York, Boston and Atlanta.


	Despite his success, Mayers' relationships with his co-founders at Superfly began deteriorating during the COVID-19 pandemic, and in August 2021, he was terminated from his position at the company. In early 2022, Mayers sued Farman, Goodstone and Black and accused them of civil misrepresentation, breach of contract and fraud for allegedly lowballing him for the value of his shares in Superfly. Also named in the complaint was Virgo Investment Group, a California private equity fund; Mayers alleged that its top executive, Jesse Watson, strung him along for months, promising $5 million in financing before firing him last summer. On Jan. 20, 2023, a New York judge dismissed the lawsuit.


	Mayers former partners at Superfly released a statement today to Billboard, writing ‚ÄúWe are heartbroken with the passing of Jonathan.  He was a cherished part of Superfly's story, woven into it's history and legacy.  In addition to the role he's played in bringing joy to millions, we will miss his razor sharp wit, infectious smile and contagious laugh.  No one could light up a room like Jon.‚Äù


	After leaving Superfly, Mayers began work on a new project called Core City Detroit which sought to raise money to invest in a ‚Äúculturally rich neighborhood anchored by a music campus providing world- class services, infrastructure, and housing for local/national artists & industry along with entertainment experiences for the public,‚Äù according to an investment deck on the project. Phase 1 of the Core City Detroit project included a drive-in diner by celebrity chef Kiki Louya and the renovation of an old pickle factory into a music production complex.


	Mayers' longtime friend Peter Shapiro, founder of Dayglo Presents and the Brooklyn Bowl, described him as a creative mastermind who had a deep love for live music and a vision for how it would evolve over the next two decades.


	‚ÄúJonathan was one of the true real visionaries of the modern concert world and one of the core minds behind Bonnaroo,‚Äù Shapiro tells Billboard. ‚ÄúModern-day festivals are all in some way built off of his vision.‚Äù


	Company officials at Another Planet Entertainment issued a statement to Billboard following Mayers' passing. ‚ÄúJonathan was a bright light, always pushing new and creative ideas in the entertainment space,‚Äù they said. ‚ÄúHe was a visionary who was integral in the founding and the spirit of Outside Lands. Everyone in the Another Planet family will miss him dearly.‚Äù

Title: Jamie Foxx Honored by Stevie Wonder at BET Awards, Gives Speech
Description:
Foxx received the Ultimate Icon Award, with tribute performances from Jennifer Hudson, Babyface, Ludacris, T-Pain, Doug E. Fresh & Tank.


													By
												

	Mackenzie Cummings-Grady



Stevie Wonder surprised everyone at the 2025 BET Awards when he stepped out to honor his longtime friend Jamie Foxx.


	During the 2025 BET Awards on Monday (June 9), Jamie Foxx was set to be honored with the Ultimate Icon Award. Throughout the night, it was teased that a ‚Äúspecial guest‚Äù would appear onstage to give Foxx his award. That guest was none other than Stevie Wonder.


	Babyface and Ludacris also popped out to pay tribute to the artistic titan, performing a cover of ‚ÄúUnpredictable‚Äù ‚Äî the Billboard Hot 100 top 10 title track from Foxx's 2005 album ‚Äî while Tank tackled a cover of Ray Charles' ‚ÄúNight Time is the Right Time.‚Äù Foxx famously portrayed Charles in the 2004 film Ray, for which he won the best actor Oscar. Jennifer Hudson then took the helm and bodied a soulful cover of ‚ÄúGold Digger,‚Äù a 10-week Hot 100 No. 1 for Ye (formerly Kanye West) and Foxx back in 2005. T-Pain and Doug E. Fresh then popped out to close out the celebration with a rockin' cover of the 2009 No. 2 Hot 100 hit ‚ÄúBlame It.‚Äù Through it all, Foxx could be seen laughing, nodding along and having a great time.


	‚ÄúJamie, look at me!‚Äù Stevie joked at the end of the show before inviting Jamie to speak. ‚ÄúI remember seeing you the first time at a club, playing piano and singing, but I knew from the moment I heard you sing that you had so much more. I admire and celebrate your talent and your love ‚Äî for blind people. I'm very happy to be here tonight to see you honored as you so very well deserve.‚Äù

	










			Trending on Billboard		







	During his acceptance speech, Foxx thanked all his friends and loved ones for showing up for him while he went through life-threatening medical complications back in 2023. He added that when he saw the ‚ÄúIn Memorium‚Äù segment, it made him reflect on his own health scare.

	











	‚ÄúYou can't go through something like that and not testify,‚Äù Foxx concluded to a roar of applause. ‚ÄúA career that I could only thank God for.‚Äù

Title: 'Carrie' TV Series Casts Heather Graham, Kate Siegel & 12 Others
Description:
By Matt Grobar 

Senior Film Reporter


EXCLUSIVE: Mike Flanagan has added 14 recurring guest stars to the cast of Carrie, his series for Amazon MGM Studios based on the iconic debut novel from Stephen King.


	Character details are under wraps. Many of the actors are veterans of Flanagan ensembles across projects like The Fall of the House of Usher, Midnight Mass and Oculus, including Kate Siegel, Michael Trucco, Katee Sackhoff, Rahul Kohli, Crystal Balint, and Danielle Klaudt. Newcomers to his circle on this project include Heather Graham (Chosen Family), Tim Bagley (The Perfect Couple), Tahmoh Penikett (The Madness), Mapuana Makia (Doogie Kamealoha M.D.), newcomer Rowan Danielle, Naika Toussaint (Washington Black), Delainey Hayles (Interview with the Vampire), and Cassandra Naud (Influencer).

	











	Summer Howell will play the title role, as previously announced. The cast will also include Siena Agudong, Matthew Lillard, Samantha Sloyan, Alison Thornton, Thalia Dudek, Siena Agudong, Amber Midthunder, Josie Totah, Arthur Conti, and Joel Oulette.




			Watch on Deadline		







	Set to serve as writer, executive producer and showrunner, while also directing select episodes, Flanagan's series reimagines the story of misfit high-schooler Carrie White, who has spent her life in seclusion with her domineering mother. After her father's sudden and untimely death, Carrie finds herself contending with the alien landscape of public high school, a bullying scandal that shatters her community, and the emergence of mysterious telekinetic powers

	











	The eight-episode series comes on the heels of four Carrie films, the most famous being Brian De Palma's from 1976, which starred Sissy Spacek. Trevor Macy will also exec produce, with Amazon MGM Studios producing.


	Siegel is repped by Paradigm, Elysian Heights, and VanderKloot Law; Trucco by Innovative Artists and Prime Talent Media; Sackoff by Innovative, Ascend Artist Representation, and Jackoway Austen Tyerman; Kohli by Artists First and McKuin Frankel Whitehead; Graham by RMS Production, Paradigm and Yorn, Levine, Barnes; Bagley by Artists & Representatives and Framework Entertainment; Penikett by RED Management and Brave Artists Management; Balint by Connekt Creative and D2 Management; Makia by Principals Talent Management and SK Management; Danielle by Peak Talent Management; Klaudt by Principals Talent; Toussaint by Thruline and MoGood Talent; Hayles by The Artists Partnership and Myman Greenspan Fox; and Naud by Play Management.

Title: Regina Hall, Sherry Cola, Arturo Castro, George Lopez & Ice Spice Join Cast Of ‚ÄòThe SpongeBob Movie: Search for SquarePants' As Paramount Premieres Opening Act & ‚ÄòSmurfs' Footage
Description:
By Melanie Goodfellow 

Senior International Film Correspondent


	Regina Hall (Honk For Jesus), Sherry Cola (Shrinking), Arturo Castro (Tron: Ares), George Lopez (Lopez vs Lopez) and rapper Ice Spice have joined the voice cast for upcoming animated feature The SpongeBob Movie: Search for SquarePants.


	Four-time Grammy multi-platinum selling rapper Isis ‚ÄúIce Spice‚Äù will also contribute a song to the movie.


	Ramsey Naito, President of Paramount Animation and Nickelodeon Animation, announced the new voice cast members during a presentation at the Annecy International Animation Film Festival on Tuesday.





	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					Annecy Title 'ChaO' To Open Japan Cuts Festival In New York City		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Inspired By 'The Princess Bride', French Animated Movie 'Pil's Adventures' Pulled In Punters After The Pandemic & Is Now Gearing Up For Some Small Screen Fun At Annecy		
			








	Naito said that the studios had a busy six months ahead with the release of Smurfs in July, and The SpongeBob Movie: Search for SquarePants in December.

	










			Watch on Deadline		







	She also noted the packed production slate topped by PAW Patrol: The Dino Movie, The Legend of Aang: The Last Airbender, and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem 2.


	Produced by Paramount Pictures with Nickelodeon Movies in association with Domain Entertainment and MRC, The SpongeBob Movie: Search for SquarePants will be released in the U.S. on December 19.


	Director Derek Drymon, who has worked on the SpongeBob SquarePants franchise on and off for more than two decades, also took to the stage to introduce the premiere of the first act of the film.


	‚ÄúIt's like coming home,‚Äù he said, before going on to talk through the artwork for the ‚Äúspooky‚Äù underwater setting of the latest installment.


	The exclusive footage of the ‚Äúfirst act‚Äù sets the scene for SpongeBob's latest adventure after he reaches the height of 36 clams and is allowed into the big people's fairground park.

	











	There he bumps into Mr. Krabs, who tells him that there is more to being grown up than height and regales him with a tale of his adventures at sea.


	SpongeBob hits on the idea of getting his swashbuckler certificate but in the process, he unwittingly summons the spirit of the Flying Dutchman.


	The evil seaman, voiced by Mark Hamill, abducts SpongeBob and Patrick Star with the aim of using them to break a curse on his back.


	Tom Kenny returns to voice SpongeBob SquarePants, with Clancy Brown (Mr. Krabs), Rodger Bumpass (Squidward), Bill Fagerbakke (Patrick), Carolyn Lawrence (Sandy), Mr. Lawrence (Plankton).


	Cola is repped by CAA, Stark Management and Ginsburg Daniels Kallis. Castro is represented by WME, Untitled Entertainment and Hansen, Jacobson, Teller, Hoberman, Newman, Warren, Richman, Rush, Kaller, Gellman, Meigs & Fox. Lopez is repped by UTA and 3 Arts.


	Based on the SpongeBob SquarePants series, created by Stephen Hillenburg, the screenplay for The SpongeBob Movie: Search for SquarePants, was written by Pam Brady and Matt Lieberman.


	Producers are Lisa Stewart, Pam Brady, Aaron Dem, alongside executive producers Marc Ceccarelli, Vincent Waller.


	The presentation also featured a sneak peek of the first 20 minutes of Smurfs featuring the voice of Rihanna for Smurfette and James Corden as No Name, whose search for identity leads to Papa Smurf being kidnapped.


	Director Chris Miller said he had wanted to remain true to the spirit and style of the original Smurfs at the same time as creating something fresh with CGI animation.


	‚ÄúIt's not about just pixels and key frames, it's about creating something that moves hearts,‚Äù he said.

Title: Mark Ruffalo To Star in The Apple Original Films Pic ‚ÄòBeing Heumann' From ‚ÄòCODA' Director Si√¢n Heder
Description:
By Justin Kroll 

Film Editor


Mark Ruffalo is set to star opposite Ruth Madeley in the Apple Original Films pic Being Heumann with CODA director Si√¢n Heder directing. The film is an adaptation of Judy Heumann's bestselling memoir.


	The script will be written by Heder and Rebekah Taussig. David Permut (Hacksaw Ridge, Face/Off) will produce alongside Kevin Walsh (Napoleon, Manchester by the Sea), whose The Walsh Company is under an overall deal with Apple. Heumann's managers John W. Beach and Kevin Cleary of Gravity Squared Entertainment will also serve as producers, with Heumann, Being Heumann co-author Kristen Joiner, and Diana Pokorny exec producing.

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	Casting
	



	
		
					Ruth Madeley Lands Lead Role In Apple's Civil Rights Film 'Being Heumann' From 'CODA's Si√¢n Heder		
			















	Casting
	



	
		
					Mark Ruffalo & Tucker Pillsbury Join Natalie Portman In Lena Dunham's Netflix Rom-Com 'Good Sex'   		
			








Being Heumann follows Heumann as she leads over a hundred disabled people to take over the San Francisco Federal Building, kicking off a 28-day sit-in in 1977. The protestors quickly form a tightly bound community, refusing to leave until the government enforces section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, which required all federal spaces to become accessible. Ruffalo will play Joseph Califano.




			Watch on Deadline		







	Heumann used a wheelchair for most of her life after contracting polio at 18 months old. She encountered discrimination early, including being denied the right to attend public school because she was considered a ‚Äúfire hazard,‚Äù and was galvanized by these experiences to get involved with the fight for disability rights. In 1970, Heumann successfully sued the New York Board of Education after being denied a teaching license solely because of her disability, thereby becoming the first wheelchair user to teach in NYC public schools. Other highlights of her career include co-founding civil rights organization Disabled in Action, helping to develop and secure the passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act, and leadership roles under both the Clinton and Obama administrations.

	











	Ruffalo can be seen next in the highly-anticipated HBO series TASK, which bows later this year. He also has the Amazon MGM Studios thriller Crime 101.


	He is repped by UTA and Lighthouse Management & Media.

Title: Billy Corgan's National Wrestling Alliance Strikes Streaming Deal With Roku
Description:
By Peter White 

Executive Editor, Television


EXCLUSIVE: Wrestling fans are set to get a new round of bouts to watch on streaming after Billy Corgan's National Wrestling Alliance struck a deal with Roku.


	The deal will see matches airing on The Roku Channel in the U.S., Canada, and Mexico, starting on July 29.


	It marks the first significant first-run deal for the association in more than 25 years.


	The league was originally founded in 1948 by wrestling promoters Paul ‚ÄúPinkie‚Äù George, Al Haft, Tony Stecher, Harry Light, Orville Brown, Don Owen and Sam Muchnick as a way to consolidate the championships of a number of regional companies into one.

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					Roku's David Eilenberg Returns To ITV America As Creative Director		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Roku Posts Solid Q1 Results, Pledging To "Remain Vigilant And Adaptable" In Uncertain Economy		
			








	The Smashing Pumpkins frontman Corgan, a big wrestling fan, bought the league in 2017.




			Watch on Deadline		







	The move will see NWA matches streaming for free every Tuesday at 8pm ET. The NWA has expanded its programing over recently years with Ten Pounds Of Gold as well as weekly broadcasts of NWA Powerrr on The CW's app.


	It is the latest sports deal for Roku, which also airs MLB Sunday Leadoff, NBA G-League, Formula E, Pro Volleyball Federation, and Bassmaster.


	‚ÄúWhen I purchased the National Wrestling Alliance in 2017, it was understood we were inheriting the history and legacy of the most storied brand in all combat sports, so to announce today we have now partnered with the number one TV streaming platform in North America is indeed a moment to be proud of,‚Äù said Corgan. ‚ÄúI look forward to sharing new episodes of ‚ÄòNWA Powerrr' with the incredible audience that Roku brings.‚Äù


	‚ÄúWe're thrilled to call The Roku Channel the streaming home of the National Wrestling Alliance, and as Billy and his team continue to excite audiences, we look forward to tapping into the scale of our platform to bring this historic and storied promotion to millions of viewers,‚Äù added Joe Franzetta, Head of Sports, Roku Media.

Title: Paramount Cutting Another 3.5% Of Its Domestic Workforce, Citing Linear TV Declines And Broader Economy
Description:
By Dade Hayes 

Business Editor


Paramount Global, which last year shed 15% of its U.S. workforce, said Tuesday it will reduce it by another 3.5%.


	The cuts will take effect Tuesday, according to a memo from Co-CEOs George Cheeks, Chris McCarthy and Brian Robbins that was obtained by Deadline.


	‚ÄúAs we navigate the continued industry-wide linear declines and dynamic macro-economic environment, while prioritizing investments in our growing streaming business, we are taking the hard, but necessary steps to further streamline our organization starting this week,‚Äù the execs wrote.





	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	Executives
	



	
		
					Paramount Global CFO Naveen Chopra Is Departing		
			















	News
	



	
		
					'60 Minutes' Correspondent Scott Pelley Says Trump Lawsuit Settlement & Apology Would Be "Very Damaging" To Reputation Of CBS And Paramount		
			








	Paramount is still in a protracted waiting game as it looks to close its $8 billion merger with Skydance Media. The transaction was proposed last summer and needs only the approval of the FCC in order to close, but it now appears unlikely to close in the first half of the year as the companies had projected. 

	










			Watch on Deadline		







	President Donald Trump's crusade against the media (in this case CBS News) is holding up the deal despite the fact that Paramount controlling shareholder Shari Redstone and Skydance backer Larry Ellison are longtime Trump supporters. Along with filing a $20 billion lawsuit over routine business activities at 60 Minutes, Trump's appointee to chair the FCC, Brendan Carr, has slow-walked the agency's review of the merger. While mediation talks are ongoing in the lawsuit, hopes have not recently been high for a near-term settlement.


	While the new layoffs are targeting domestic workers, the Co-CEOs said they ‚Äúmay also result in some impacts to our workforce outside the U.S. over time.‚Äù

	











	At the end of 2024, Paramount had 18,600 global employees, with Tuesday's cutbacks affecting several hundred in the U.S. As opposed to the multi-phase layoffs last year, which were announced in the summer and wrapped by year-end, the new round is taking effect Tuesday.


	‚ÄúWe recognize how difficult this is and are very thankful for everyone's hard work and contributions,‚Äù the CEOs wrote.‚ÄØ‚ÄùThese changes are necessary to address the environment we are operating in and best position Paramount for success.‚Äù


	The shrinking of Paramount's workforce reflects contraction across the entire media sector, with Disney recently announcing a fresh round of cuts as companies reckon with cord-cutting's hit to their pay-TV revenues.

Title: ‚ÄòDexter's Laboratory' & ‚ÄòThe Powerpuff Girls' Creators On How They Broke The System At Cartoon Network
Description:
By Max Goldbart 

International TV Co-Editor


	If he was starting out today, Dexter's Laboratory creator Genndy Tartakovsky would ‚Äúmake cartoon after cartoon until something hits.‚Äù 


	That was Tartakovsky's pearl of wisdom delivered to a packed Annecy audience as he celebrated 25 years of Cartoon Network Studios with a sextet of creators of some of the biggest American cartoons of all time, including The Powerpuff Girls, Adventure Time and Steven Universe.


	Tartakovsky, who is also in Annecy promoting Netflix's Fixed, figures it's easier than ever to get your big break because young cartoonists can flood YouTube with ideas.





	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					From Brink Of Bankruptcy, TeamTO Unveils Six New Shows & Adult Animation Push At Annecy		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Neil Court Joins Coolabi As Chairman Amid 'Warrior Cats' Growth Push And M&A Opportunities		
			








	‚ÄúIt's partly independent now because you can make it and put it on your own kind of cable channel,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúThat's what I'd do [if I were starting now]. I'd work a day job and then at night I'd make cartoon after cartoon until something hits. It was more difficult when we were coming up.‚Äù 

	










			Watch on Deadline		







	Tartakovsky is enthused by the new landscape and said he ‚Äúfeels like when I was younger, I feel like that energy makes me still want to do new things.‚Äù


	He sat next to his old friend and The Powerpuff Girls creator Craig McCracken, who concurred, saying that for his spin-off of Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends, which he is making with Warner-owned Hanna Barbera Studios Europe, ‚Äúthe energy is so Cartoon Network‚Äù on set. 


	Adam Muto, showrunner of Adventure Time, was slightly more muted on the current state of things.


	‚ÄúWe need to make sure people with idiosyncrasies get to have their own voices,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut [commissioners] have to greenlight stuff. They have gotta greenlight.‚Äù


‚ÄúWe were breaking the system‚Äù


	Tartakovsky and McCracken walked the Annecy audience through how they broke the system at Cartoon Network Studios a quarter century ago when they were first starting out, with Tartakovsky describing the older generation of cartoonists back then as being ‚Äúbeaten down‚Äù when he landed his Dexter's Laboratory greenlight as a young man.


	McCracken, who worked with Tartakosvky on Dexter's Laboratory, added: ‚ÄúWe were breaking the system and they didn't like that. They were survivalists and we had been given an opportunity they had been working their whole lives for. I felt a bit bad for them but we were given this golden opportunity, this one seven-minute show. And to be fair some of the old guard loved what we were doing.‚Äù 

	











	Tartakosvky set the scene for the early days of Dexter's Lab, which went on to achieve the rare feat of being a primetime Emmy-nominated cartoon. ‚ÄúHalf the crew were high,‚Äù he joked. ‚ÄúI felt like I was saying, ‚ÄòGuys come on this is our one shot,' and then they wouldn't start working till 2 p.m.‚Äù


	He said he was ‚Äúso worried about getting fired‚Äù that he ‚Äúdidn't have a minute to focus on anything apart from what I was doing.‚Äù 


	Soon after, McCracken's Powerpuff Girls landed a greenlight, making him into a star of the animation world, but this wasn't plain sailing either. McCracken spoke of experiencing the worst focus group of his life with a group of 11-year-old boys, one of whom even called for the ‚Äúcreator to be fired.‚Äù At the time, Cartoon Network executive Mike Lazzo convinced McCracken that it was better to have people hate the show than be indifferent, and he was told to push ahead.


	‚ÄúI had to get out of my own head and tell myself to stop being so arty,‚Äù said McCracken. ‚ÄúWe felt we could make cartoons at the time so we said let's make this the best thing it can be.‚Äù


	The pair were joined on stage by four younger cartoon creators including Muto, Regular Show's JG Quintel, Steven Universe creator Rebecca Sugar and Adventure Time‚Äòs Pendleton Ward.


	This quartet, who were termed the ‚Äúsecond generation‚Äù of Cartoon Network voices, had an intriguing discussion around fear of failure.


	‚ÄúThe first season we thought we'd get canned every moment,‚Äù said Muto. ‚ÄúIt was during a transitional moment [for Cartoon Network] and our shows had to be hits.‚Äù


	Quintel said creatives live in fear at the start of their journeys that ‚Äúif these are bad, then we're getting in trouble.‚Äù 


	For Sugar, who is the first non-binary person to independently create a series for the network, it was  ‚Äúless about competition and more about protection‚Äù at the start of her journey.


	‚ÄúI learned when showrunning that when there is something specific on a board, you have to think how to protect it,‚Äù she explained. 


	Sugar was delighted to sit on the same stage as Tartakovsky. She recalled pitching him an early version of Steven Universe. When Tartakosvky said he'd direct an ep, ‚ÄúI crashed my car into a pole on the way home,‚Äù Sugar added. 


	The group were speaking at Annecy on the same day as Matt Groening.

Title: Fans React To Taylor Swift & Travis Kelce's ‚ÄòSecret Marriage'
Description:
Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce fans are becoming more convinced that the power couple is secretly married, thanks to a tiny detail spotted in an unsuspecting photo.

On Monday, June 9, Cole Kmet and Emily Jarosz's wedding planner, Ellie Nottoli, shared details of the couple's big day on Instagram, including ‚Äúlove notes‚Äù for the guests.

Eagle-eyed fans quickly zeroed in on a light blue envelope addressed to Swift and Kelce, confirming the power couple was on the guest list. But what made it eyebrow-raising was the way the couple's name was written.

The envelope, featuring elegant calligraphy that read ‚ÄúTaylor and Travis Kelce‚Äù alongside a ‚ÄúTable 13‚Äù seating assignment, quickly stirred excitement among fans. Apparently, many take this as proof that the singer and NFL star are now husband and wife.

One excited fan commented on X, ‚ÄúWould be a welcome surprise for them! If true, hope they always share happiness together.‚Äù

Another speculated, ‚ÄúI think they're married in court. The real wedding will happen later.‚Äù

Someone wrote, ‚ÄúThis feels like something we shouldn't be seeing,‚Äù while another chimed in, ‚ÄúTaylor Kelce, it has a lovely ring to it.‚Äù

Meanwhile, some were not convinced that Swift and Kelce are actually married now. One fan pointed out, ‚ÄúThis is very common for couples (married and unmarried) for weddings. It's the aesthetic.‚Äù

Another shared the same sentiment, ‚ÄúI'm engaged, but even when we were dating, invited would be addressed to ‚Äò<fianc√©s name> and <fianc√©'s last name>'. It's not that weird. It's solely for aesthetic purposes.‚Äù

Swift and Kelce skipped Kmet and Jarosz's wedding, but they did step out for another nuptials on Friday, June 6, per People. The couple attended Kelce's cousin Tanner Corum's wedding in Tennessee. 

Whether or not the rumors of a secret marriage are true, Swift and Kelce's relationship is stronger than ever. According to Daily Mail, everyone is just waiting for the two to take their relationship to the next level.

A source told the outlet that Swift's parents are ready to give their blessing to Kelce when he asks for her hand in marriage.

‚ÄúNothing seems to be imminent, but it will 100 percent happen,‚Äù the insider added. ‚ÄúTaylor and Travis are treating this relationship as their last relationship, and when they get engaged, when they get married and when they start a family, it will be exactly when it is meant to happen.‚Äù

Title: Keanu Reeves Has Perfect Reaction to Jonathan Groff Straddling Him at Tony Awards
Description:
The crowd watched Jonathan Groff intently as he launched into the songs ‚ÄúMack the Knife,‚Äù ‚ÄúThat's All,‚Äù and ‚ÄúOnce in a Lifetime‚Äù at the 2025 Tony Awards. But he really grabbed everyone's attention when he came into the crowd and jumped onto Keanu Reeves' chair. The ‚ÄúJohn Wick‚Äù actor stared up in mock horror as he became a part of the show.

Reeves could've had many reactions to his former co-star bringing him into the spotlight. His decision to fully embrace the moment just made us love him even more.

Groff jumped off the stage and quickly spotted Reeves. He jumped onto Reeves' chair, straddling him, singing ‚Äúand the only heart I own is for you and you alone.‚Äù 

‚ÄúI can only give you country walks in springtime, and a hand to hold when leaves begin to fall,‚Äù he continued. He caressed Reeves' hair and chest while Reeves looked up at him, displaying an exaggerated look of surprise. But as the camera zoomed in, Reeves looked thrilled, making devil horns ‚Äî the rock n' roll symbol, with both hands.

Groff was nominated in the Best Performance by a Leading Actor in a Musical category for his role as Bobby Darin in ‚ÄúJust in Time.‚Äù He previously told Vogue that he wanted to ‚Äúbreak the fourth wall with the audience to create that connection that Bobby was really famous for.‚Äù He created that connection at the 2025 Tony Awards.

Reeves and Groff aren't strangers; the two co-starred in ‚ÄúThe Matrix Resurrections.‚Äù Groff played a version of Agent Smith, previously played by Hugo Weaving.

The ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù actor earned the nickname ‚ÄúThe Savage‚Äù on set because he gave his all to the fight scenes. He admitted to GQ that he was determined to perfect one particular fight sequence. Groff trained more for ‚ÄúThe Matrix‚Äù than he had for any of his Broadway shows. He wanted to ensure he ‚Äúcould actually be present with one of the greatest action stars of our generation.‚Äù

Groff told The Hollywood Reporter that working with Reeves was ‚Äúan experience I'll hold in my heart for the rest of my life.‚Äù 

‚ÄúIt was so exciting to be doing such extraordinary fight choreography with the greatest action star of our time and someone that's so devoted to their craft,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI really tried to take in every single moment of getting to be with Keanu and I learned so much from working with him.

Title: ‚ÄòAmerican Idol' Finalists Rally Around Josh King Amid Hospitalization
Description:
As North Carolina musician Josh King advanced all the way to the top eight on season 23 of ‚ÄúAmerican Idol,‚Äù he bravely admitted how scared he was to lose the friendships he'd forged with his fellow finalists once the show was over. But on June 9, 2025, King revealed that those friends were still there for him as he spent several days in the hospital. 

King, 23, posted a photo of himself in his hospital bed flanked by two friends from ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù ‚Äî Skylie Marie Thompson, who made it to the Hollywood Week Showstopper round, and top 24 singer Grayson Torrence. They were part of a songwriting retreat that King had traveled to Virginia to be part of, hosted by another Hollywood Week contestant, Nina Daig, he wrote on Instagram. 

Although the weekend started well, King woke up one morning in ‚Äúexcruciating pain,‚Äù barely able to move, and wound up in the hospital for several days. Doctors diagnosed the singer and piano player with a potentially life-threatening condition, but King said he's on the mend and grateful for his ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù family, near and far, who rallied around him. 

A post shared by Josh King (@officialjoshking)

After the first two days of the songwriting retreat held at Daig's house, King wrote that, after feeeling a little ‚Äúiffy,‚Äù he ‚Äúwent to sleep and woke up the next morning entirely unable to move. I was in such excruciating pain that I evacuated anything that remained in my stomach üòÄ‚Äù 

Daig's husband took King to the hospital, where they found his resting heart rate was high, a ‚Äústeady 125-130 bpm for most of Saturday,‚Äù he wrote, ‚Äúand any ounce of movement hurt like hell.‚Äù 

‚ÄúI don't quite know what it was exactly,‚Äù King shared, adding that the doctors diagnosed him with SIRS, or systemic inflammatory response syndrome, which the Cleveland Clinic describes as ‚Äúa life-threatening medical emergency caused by your body's overwhelming response to a stressor‚Äù which can include an ‚Äúinfection, trauma or a worsening health condition.‚Äù 

‚ÄúThe doctor said there was a ton of strain on my heart as a result,‚Äù King wrote, ‚Äúand I had to be monitored for the next two nights. The cause was a combination of things, dehydration, fatigue, stress, heat exhaustion, etc.‚Äù 

King said he was released from the hospital on June 9 was ‚Äúon the mend‚Äù but that he'd been ‚Äúseverely unlucky regarding the state of my health‚Äù in recent weeks. 

King, who performed on the ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù season finale with Jessica Simpson, concluded his post by writing, ‚ÄúIdol family was there for me once again when I needed them :)‚Äù

Torrence posted a selfie video on the night of June 9 to tell fans, ‚ÄúJosh is doing a lot better, he's out of the hospital,‚Äù but that he would be staying in Virginia for several days and they'd be able to work on songs as he recovers. She encouraged fans to leave kind words and prayers for him in the comment section of his post.  

Among those who've already commented are some of his fellow ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù finalists, including third-place finisher Breanna Nix, who wrote, ‚Äúoh no! I'm happy you're out!! Please rest though!!!‚Äù

Canaan James Hill, who was attending the BET Awards, wrote, ‚ÄúGlad to hear you're okay brother! Love you man ü§ùüèæüíØ‚Äù

Ch√© Chesterman chimed in, ‚ÄúWish you well brother ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äù and Desmond Roberts wrote, ‚ÄúSo glad you're alive manüôèüèæ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äù

During his ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù journey, King was heralded for encouraging the ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù judges to save 16-year-old Mattie Pruitt instead of him, advancing her into the top 7. Host Ryan Seacrest also revealed that King has volunteered every week for the last several years with young patients at Seacrest Studios inside Charlotte's Levine Children's Hospital.

Title: HGTV's Christina Haack Shares Relief Over Latest Bloodwork Results
Description:
After facing multiple health challenges in recent years, longtime HGTV star Christina Haack is celebrating her latest lab results. 

‚ÄúToday I found out my bloodwork is the best it's ever been,‚Äù Haack wrote in an update via her Instagram Stories on June 9, 2025, noting that she started seeing a ‚Äúregenerative health practitioner‚Äù in 2018. 

Haack continued with her update, written in white text on a black background, ‚ÄúAll my inflammation & autoimmune numbers are great. This just shows how much stress can truly negatively affect your health. üôè‚ù§Ô∏èüò•‚Äù

Haack's results are a huge relief after several years of nerve-wracking health challenges and the stress of her third marriage ending in July 2024.

In early 2023, the ‚ÄúChristina on the Coast‚Äù star shared that she underwent ‚Äúextensive‚Äù testing to try to figure out why she'd been feeling so under the weather. 

She shared in her Instagram Stories that January, ‚ÄúI did an expensive, super extensive panel and I got all my results back for, like, 100 different types of molds and metals and bacterias. And my highest level of toxicity came back as an abnormal amount of gut bacteria, which is like SIBO, and also parasites.‚Äù 

According to the Mayo Clinic, SIBO stands for Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth, which is the result of ‚Äúan abnormal increase in the overall bacterial population in the small intestine ‚Äî particularly types of bacteria not commonly found in that part of the digestive tract.‚Äù

Haack shared a page of her test results at the time, which were ordered by her doctor at Lee Regenerative Medical Institute, an alternative medicine practice in Huntington Beach, California. Rather than opt for traditional remedies, such as antibiotics or surgery, the HGTV star took a holistic route,  including a ‚Äúdetox‚Äù regimen. 

‚ÄúSo I'm on a cleanse and a parasite cleanse and I heard it gets worse before it gets better,‚Äù she said in a video she posted to her Stories. ‚ÄúIt's pretty brutal, but I'm hoping at the end, I feel good.‚Äù

Haack told People in 2020 that she'd been diagnosed with Hashimoto's disease, an autoimmune disorder that can cause hypothyroidism, and that paying close attention to her nutrition had helped some. But in 2021, she shared on Instagram that her ‚Äúextreme stomach pain‚Äù had continued.   

‚ÄúIt has been written off as stress and doctors have tried to put me on all the pills / meds but luckily I realized masking it wasn't the answer,‚Äù she wrote at the time. ‚ÄúI wanted to fix the problem so I really focused on my nutrition and it seemed to get better but then last year it was triggered again and all of a sudden the stomach pain was back.‚Äù

Haack's health challenges continued into the next year. In April 2024, Haack shared that she'd made a ‚Äúpretty disturbing‚Äù discovery about a root canal she'd had several years earlier, revealing in her Instagram Stories that she was going to have oral surgery for a lingering infection. 

‚ÄúWhen I was 16, I had a tooth injury to a back molar and had to have an emergency root canal,‚Äù Haack wrote in her Stories. ‚ÄúIn 2020, my dentist saw via xray the previous root canal showed signs of being infected. So I went and had it redone.‚Äù

‚ÄúFast forward to last week,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúThe infection came back‚Ä¶so I've had an infection that I have zero symptoms of lingering for years and years!! Pretty disturbing.‚Äù

‚ÄúI'm taking care of it next week via explant,‚Äù Haack told her fans, ‚Äúbut leaving an infection that long can cause all kinds of health complications. With no root you can't feel there is a problem.‚Äù

According to the American Association of Endodonists, it's rare but possible for root canals to become infected again. In most situations, per the AAE, patients undergo a ‚Äúcomplex‚Äù endodontic retreatment procedure to remove infection and save the tooth.

Title: Balance Is Why Chrishell Stause and G Flip's Relationship Works
Description:
Even if you're a reality television star, not everything needs to be blasted out to the world. At least that is what ‚ÄúSelling Sunset‚Äù star Chrishell Stause has learned.  After very public heartbreaks and splits from Justin Hartley and Jason Oppenheim, she has found lasting love that she chooses to keep a little more private.

Stause met G Flip, an Australian musician, on the set of a music video, and as they say, the rest is history. After a whirlwind romance, a private wedding ceremony, and matching tattoos, according to Us Weekly, the couple is now working on starting a family. 

Right from the start, Stause and G Flip treated their relationship as if it were different. By the time they married in May 2023, privacy was one of their top priorities. ‚ÄúIt was very untraditional. Elvis was there! So, it was great,‚Äù Stause said of the wedding, exclusively to Entertainment Tonight. 

‚ÄúIt just really meant a lot for us. And it was‚Ä¶ the best day of all time,‚Äù Stause shared, adding that the privacy around the wedding was to avoid unwanted, unsolicited feedback. ‚ÄúI just feel like some of those things you don't want to hear people's opinions on. It was perfect. It was amazing. It was nice to kind of keep things private and to ourselves so that we could really enjoy it. Then, once we felt ready to share, now it's exciting because we get to kind of live in it all over again. So, it's nice.‚Äù

The couple also locked in their commitment with matching tattoos of their wedding vows. Chrishell is proud of her relationship and says, ‚ÄúI really wanted to validate our love and really feel like we let people know that this is, you know, this isn't something silly, [or that] we're just having fun. We have big plans for each other. And I think that that's something that, in the scope of the world today, it's something that I was happy to share, and it's something that I really am proud about.‚Äù

One of the things that seems to work for this couple is staying candid about their lives, without totally oversharing every detail. It is one of the things that makes Chrishell and G Flip's relationship somewhat relatable to their fans. Two years after tying the knot, they are now focused on starting a family via adoption. 

Chrishell told Us Weekly earlier this spring, ‚ÄúWe've kept the details a little under wraps, just because I don't think it helps anybody to go into all the details. But I'll just say to anyone that understands this [adoption] process ‚Äî there are just a lot of different roadblocks, and so we do feel like we're on the upswing.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are feeling really positive about where we're at currently. And I will tell you this ‚Äî nobody will be happier to report good news than me when it's that time. So, until then, I just really feel like everything happens for a reason.‚Äù

Title: 'Materialists': Celine Song on Dating and 'Sex and the City' Influence
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

The Monday morning I sat down with Celine Song in New York City, where she lives and where her hotly awaited new film ‚ÄúMaterialists‚Äù is set, came about an hour after reviews broke. Led by an appealing cast and doubling as a breezy romance and an incisive critique of modern dating, ‚ÄúMaterialists‚Äù is her second movie as a director, and her first since ‚ÄúPast Lives‚Äù turned Song into the Oscar-nominated belle of the 2023-2024 awards season.

Reactions pouring in were going well, as most reviews (including IndieWire's) reacted positively to writer/director Song's portrait of matchmaker-to-the-moneyed Lucy (Dakota Johnson), who balances the clinical outlook on romance her job demands with an unexpected love triangle between herself, a lethally charming private-equity broker and potential client named Harry (Pedro Pascal), and her less-polished, struggling-actor ex John (Chris Evans). But Song, she said, doesn't read reviews. She leaves that task to her husband, ‚ÄúChallengers‚Äù and ‚ÄúQueer‚Äù screenwriter Justin Kuritzkes, to deliver the highlights.

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòThe Phoenician Scheme' Production Design Stretches Even Wes Anderson's Theatricality to the Limit Studio Ghibli at 40: Can an Ethical Animation Studio Still Exist, or Even Survive? 

‚ÄúWe do this for each other. Just because [reading reviews] sort of distances the movie, too,‚Äù Song told IndieWire. ‚ÄúThe thing that you made is this thing that is, in a way, totally intangible. To see it in paper adjudicated and judged, even if it's so positive and wonderful, which is true, too, still, it's turned into words where it's being evaluated. There is a bit of it where it feels sad, you know? Even if it's good. I love hearing that it's good. I love it when he reads me snippets, like, ‚ÄòOK, this is good,' but it's nothing to do [with] the movie anymore.‚Äù She laughed, ‚ÄúIt's no longer mine!‚Äù

 










Song's latest movie takes the shape of the classic '90s rom-coms (think Nora Ephron) or rom-drams (think James L. Brooks) nobody makes for theaters anymore, but it has more on its mind, and is perhaps more cannily sociological than its predecessors. For one, Lucy lives in debt and out of her means on an $80,000 annual salary (which, a sad reality, for a single New Yorker living on their own in a studio or a one-bedroom as she does is at the low end of livable). For another, her clients, including Sophie (Zo√´ Winters), come to her frayed by the dating market, likely arriving at the matchmaking service Adore (run by Marin Ireland's character) after striking out once again on the apps.

Song's breakout ‚ÄúPast Lives‚Äù ‚Äî a ruminative, what-might-have-been walk-and-talk about a married Korean-American immigrant (Greta Lee) who reconnects with her childhood best friend and potential lost flame (Teo Yoo), premiered at Sundance 2023. Ecstatic acclaim and awards ambitions from A24 suddenly flung the first-time feature filmmaker (who got her creative start in the New York theater world after moving to Canada from Korea with her family when she was 12) onto the long-haul festival and awards circuit, which demands a lot from anyone. It would be more than a year until she finally attended the 2024 Oscars, where ‚ÄúPast Lives‚Äù was nominated for Best Picture, but in between, she attended innumerable fests and awards ceremonies to represent her critical darling.

 










‚ÄúI can imagine, in 10 years, I'll be like, ‚ÄòI can't do that!'‚Äù Song laughed. ‚ÄúBut the first movie, I felt like I could do it, and I liked getting to know different festivals and different sides of the release internationally. How's it doing in Spain? Again, the topic was love, which I could talk about forever. It wasn't like I was talking about something difficult.‚Äù

Journalists speculated as to why A24 opted to skip festivals and take ‚ÄúMaterialists,‚Äù which wrapped in New York in Spring 2024, directly to theaters for a wide release this summer. It's opening on June 13 in around 2,800 theaters; ‚ÄúPast Lives‚Äù started in four theaters with a platform release two years ago, playing eventually at most in just over 900 to gross $11 million by the end of a nine-month run. (The fizzy rom-com-centered marketing on ‚ÄúMaterialists,‚Äù meanwhile, may turn out to be a bait-and-switch for what is a deeper drama in the end, but early social sentiment was high even before reviews.)

‚ÄúThey're a studio. They're the ones who tell me what they think. But they do care, more than the other studios, about [creativity] and what the filmmaker wants. When they were talking about me ‚Äî ‚Äòthis is the plan' ‚Äî I got really excited. I was like, really? You think? That's so cool,‚Äù Song said. ‚ÄúI wanted an amazing experience like that, because I had an amazing, beautiful experience releasing ‚ÄòPast Lives' ‚Ä¶ With this movie, I'm trying to do something different. Similarly, I want to have a different experience releasing the movie.‚Äù

 










As for the films and literature that inspired ‚ÄúMaterialists‚Äù ‚Äî which is so much caught up in the mathematics of love, its operations and behavior as an economically driven apparatus grounded in value, mutual exchange, and investment ‚Äî it was Brooks, Ephron, even Billy Wilder. ‚ÄúThere was a whole era where you just get to show up to a movie where people are going through things, and there's so much romance, and it's going to be about love because it's the thing we are all interested in. It's also about the way life works.‚Äù

But Jane Austen, ever the literary master of tracing how romance also is and must be a kind of business deal pivoted around a woman's life station, also spoke to Song (whose academic studies have included psychology, philosophy, and playwriting) and ‚ÄúMaterialists.‚Äù ‚ÄúVictorian romances are really in touch with the material reality and the pressures of marriage, the pressures of partnering, especially for women whose only way at the time to have any power or security or prosperity was through marriage,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIn 2025, women can have jobs, they can have lucrative salaries, an amazing career, but amazingly, there's still material pressures of partnership that still pervade differently.‚Äù

Women, she said, like Lucy, who is ‚Äúnot somebody who was born rich and feels like she has to fit into the wealthy world that allows her to do the work that she does. She's always going to live a little bit beyond her means, which is quite relatable for New Yorkers: You set a budget for rent, and then you end up paying $500 more,‚Äù Song said. Lucy, though, because of her job duties and past disappointments in love, can only at first see romance and marriage in terms of numbers, which is why when she meets Harry at a client's glitzy wedding, she grills him about his income, his height, and his background without even attempting to interrogate his essence as a person, his interests beyond the status signifiers that could make him a suitable match.

 










As ‚ÄúMaterialists‚Äù is a love story about singles navigating New York City, of course, ‚ÄúSex and the City‚Äù and its own Austenian contemplations of the metrics of dating life and how wealth and privilege play a factor in courtship, come to mind not just among the audience but for Song, too.

‚ÄúThe thing about ‚ÄòSex and the City' is that now, sometimes you rewatch it, and you're like, ‚ÄòThose are some old ideas about gender!'‚Äù laughed Song, who like any romantic New Yorker or even aspiring ones raised herself artistically on the show to a degree, too. ‚ÄúBut some of those things you realize, you grew up imagining what it is like to live in an unconventional way as a working woman. It's one of the longest-lasting [stories about] being a woman and also being a woman who is not necessarily likeable 100 percent of the time. There's some element where it was always completely relatable, and then you also fall in love with New York City through that show. You get to know everything about where you want to go. They'll be like, ‚ÄòIn downtown‚Ä¶,' and we'll be like, ‚ÄòOoh, downtown!' And I'll be watching from Toronto.‚Äù

‚ÄúSex and the City,‚Äù which Song praised as never ‚Äúmoralizing,‚Äù is about a fantasy of New York City, a fantasy of being a single person, and the kind of fantasy Song both tributes and even debunks in ‚ÄúMaterialists.‚Äù Her film, though, takes us to parts of New York we didn't see in the HBO series or even now on its HBO Max counterpart ‚ÄúAnd Just Like That‚Äù or rarely in Manhattan love stories, like Brooklyn's Bushwick, where John stars in a new play (‚ÄúTom and Eliza,‚Äù named for Song's own 2016 prize-winning stage work), or the bayside Sunset Park, where he lives in a cramped three-bedroom with two chaotic roommates.

 










‚ÄúWhen I scripted it in 2022, I thought he would be living in Bushwick, and then, me and my location manager realized that Bushwick has been so far gentrified that it just wouldn't make any sense,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt would be too expensive for him. I don't give a fuck about this New York real estate. But that's why we were like, what's a place that's not fully gentrified, where as an actor you have two roommates and pay that much, and are in a sweet situation and can't move and the apartment's shitty?‚Äù

Song may not give a fuck about New York real estate, but her movie is as interested in the balance sheets endemic to human romances as it is the emotions needed to sustain them at all.

‚ÄúHave you become so completely wrapped up in the numbers and the algorithm and the way that we objectify and commodify ourselves that that's what we're considering more real than true love?‚Äù Song wondered, pondering her movie's true theme. ‚ÄúThe character Sophie says, ‚ÄòI'm not merchandise. I'm a person.' What does it mean to be a person right now? Is it actually the way it seems on Instagram? ‚ÄòMaterialists' is really interested in the dating market. That's the job Lucy has, that's where the cynicism is from. The dating market existed in Victorian romances ‚Äî it was kind of local, the garden parties, the actual gossip. Now, the marriage market is on their phones. You can go to Instagram and compare your own value as a data point ‚Ä¶ in comparison to everyone else.‚Äù

 










She continued, ‚ÄúThere is an endless self-commodification and self-objectification. All the language we have around self-improvement, for example. Like, ‚ÄòEverybody's getting Botox. Why don't you get Botox? Do you not want to invest in your face?' They talk about it as an investment. ‚ÄòYou're going to look so much better. You're going to be improved.' There's a very insidious conversation about improving your value ‚Ä¶ at the end of the day, what you're trying to say is that you're merchandise, you're for sale, so you should improve your value, just like how you improve anything you're trying to sell. Everything comes down to Sophie's line: ‚ÄòI'm not merchandise. I'm a person.' It's fun to play the game and objectify ourselves and each other. It's catty. But the end of that is going to be dehumanization.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaterialists‚Äù opens in theaters from A24 on Friday, June 13.

Title: Studio Ghibli at 40: Can an Ethical Animation Studio Still Exist, or Even Survive?
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Studio Ghibli's prestigious reputation consists of truths and exaggerations. The company has spent 40 years as a world leader in quality animation while independently funding projects based on prior successes ‚Äî until their sale to Nippon TV in 2023.

Behind every great library of art is a machine that needs to sell it, and Ghibli, which turns 40 this June, is no different. As much as we laud the altruistic, ethical enterprise established by Toshio Suzuki, Isao Takahata, and Hayao Miyazaki, Ghibli can be just as cynical as its Western counterparts. 

 










Ghibli's branding as an ethical animation studio isn't unfounded. Rayna Denison, author of ‚ÄúStudio Ghibli: An Industrial History,‚Äù has admired the thoughtful way Suzuki, Takahata, and Miyazaki constructed the studio. 




			Popular on IndieWire		




Related Stories Celine Song on Why ‚ÄòMaterialists' Skipping Festivals for Theaters Was the Right Move ‚Äî and the Irresistible Influence of ‚ÄòSex and the City' ‚ÄòThe Phoenician Scheme' Production Design Stretches Even Wes Anderson's Theatricality to the Limit 

‚ÄúThey put deep thought into what they wanted to do with their studio before they founded it,‚Äù Denison told IndieWire. ‚ÄúYou get early interviews with Miyazaki saying things like, ‚ÄòIf you're only hiring people on temporary contracts, then they're not really your employees, so you can't expect much from them.' He makes jokes about how if he has to turn his air conditioning off to save money to pay people's salaries, he's willing to sweat through the entire summer for the sake of animation. Miyazaki came out of a left-leaning union movement in the 1960s, so I think he had started thinking about a better way to make animation. That's why Ghibli has a creche, and there are places to put your bicycle, all these little touches that are very Miyazaki.‚Äù

 










For Michael Leader, co-host of the ‚ÄúGhibliotheque‚Äù podcast and co-author of ‚ÄúGhibliverse‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Animation Atlas,‚Äù the works of Studio Ghibli rise above the conversation about animation being a kids' medium. 

‚ÄúThey go all the way back to the basic idea of storytelling,‚Äù Leader said. ‚ÄúIf you think about when storytelling was just people around a campfire, it would be aimed at whoever was there. They never said, ‚ÄòThis is a story for kids.' It's how they made sense of the world. But then these folk tales become fairy tales, which become bedtime stories for kids, and then they're turned into something for Disney, and suddenly it's just kids stuff. But actually, when it's done well, it's wise, it's got life lessons, it's got a worldview. Miyazaki and Takahata mostly made work for younger audiences, but it has the wisdom and worldview and craft and skill of any sort of story.‚Äù

The miracle of Miyazaki's movies is that he's able to make such thoughtful art while setting box office records. 1997's ‚ÄúPrincess Mononoke‚Äù was the highest-grossing release of all time in Japan until ‚ÄúTitanic‚Äù arrived that same year. His mentor/older-brother-figure, Isao Takahata, had some successes but ultimately different goals. 

‚ÄúThe difference between Miyazaki and Takahata is that Takahata tried to push the envelope of what animation can do and who it is for,‚Äù said Denison. ‚ÄúWhen they released [1991's] ‚ÄòOnly Yesterday,' the promotional magazines for it had interviews with adult professional women from across Japan. It was aimed squarely at women who were in their 20s and 30s. It was a really risky thing for him to do, but this is what Takahata did at Ghibli. They gave him the freedom to experiment and to push the limits of Japanese animation.‚Äù

 










Not only were Takahata's films more experimental than Miyazaki's, but he also had a less conventional way of working. ‚ÄúYou always take [studio CEO] Suzuki's stories with a grain of salt, because he loves to tell a story,‚Äù said Leader. ‚ÄúBut he claims that after Miyazaki made loads of money from ‚ÄòNausica√§ of the Valley of the Wind,' he said to Takahata, ‚ÄòI'd like to fund you to make another film. I've been to this area of the country where there's a beautiful canal system where you could maybe set an animated film.' Takahata comes back with a three-hour documentary. It's really slow and goes way over budget, meaning Miyazaki had to make another sweeping adventure film, and that's where ‚ÄòCastle in the Sky' came from.‚Äù

Even Takahata's ‚ÄúGrave of the Fireflies,‚Äù widely regarded as a masterpiece, was mired by the director's approach to his work. ‚ÄúTakahata missed the deadline [for ‚ÄòGrave'],‚Äù said Leader. ‚ÄúIt was released unfinished, which was professionally embarrassing. No one would fund another Takahata project because he blows budgets, misses deadlines, and delivers a film unfinished. So Miyazaki really put himself on the line to get ‚ÄòOnly Yesterday' made.‚Äù 

For Leader, this hammers home the unreality of a studio without an intense marketing machine around it. ‚ÄúYou need your films to be bought and watched, because that's how they become embedded in the culture, how they pass between generations. No animation studio in the world has that freedom to completely self-finance based on the legacy of what they've done, unless your dad owns Nike.‚Äù

 










One of the main ways Ghibli finances its work is through merchandise, an industrial complex unto itself.

‚ÄúInitially, Toshio Suzuki agreed to put a cap on merchandising profits, so they weren't looking to massively exploit what was available to them,‚Äù said Denison. ‚ÄúBut when they briefly shut the studio in 2014, they really shifted modes, and we've seen an explosion in Ghibli merchandising. It was also really important to the early life of the studio, and it allowed the studio to become a permanent enterprise. The success of Totoro and then Jiji merchandise mattered when they were trying to build their own studio in the early 1990s and have a permanent home for Studio Ghibli.‚Äù

Then, 1989 proved to be a pivotal year for the studio. ‚ÄúMy Neighbor Totoro‚Äù first showed on TV and launched a demand for plushies, while Ghibli found their first theatrical hit in ‚ÄúKiki's Delivery Service.‚Äù That's also when Ghibli began telling stories about women. ‚ÄúWhen they're promoting ‚ÄòKiki's Delivery Service,' it's seen as another girl-focused movie, following on from ‚ÄòMy Neighbor Totoro,' so they're becoming known for Shoujo animation,‚Äù said Denison. ‚Äú‚ÄòKiki' was also sold on the idea of how one overcomes depression. I find that fascinating from a relatively young studio, in what should just be a girl's adventure movie, to be dealing with psychological blocks and maturity and becoming a mature version of yourself and finding your power again as a woman.‚Äù

 










Spin is key to Ghibli's success, being able to market themselves as blockbuster filmmakers in Japan and as prestigious ‚Äúworld cinema‚Äù filmmakers elsewhere. The person chiefly tasked with finding a marketing spin on Hayao Miyazaki's and Takahata's work is Toshio Suzuki, a man described by Goro Miyazaki as ‚Äúa dark wizard who makes me do things I don't want to.‚Äù 

As much as he's a master marketer, Suzuki is also an incredibly talented producer, constantly getting the best from his directors. ‚ÄúHe's trying to bring these generational talents together and make them play off each other, do some behind-the-scenes wrangling and ego management to make them do something great,‚Äù said Leader.

What Suzuki most notably helped realize was Ghibli's sheen of prestige. ‚ÄúThey became known as the anti-Disney,‚Äù said Leader. ‚ÄúDisney sold out years ago. They became about selling theme parks and cruises and characters in suits and Disney adults and being emblematic of American imperialism. Ghibli was seen as something of substance, something handcrafted and beautiful, which plays into orientalist tropes about Japan.‚Äù

Miyazaki being pushed to the forefront, mostly due to the way audiences respond to his movies, risks diminishing the work of everyone else at the studio. ‚ÄúWe haven't talked about Yoshifumi Kondo, Hiromasa Yonebayashi or Goro Miyazaki, these other directors who are doing interesting works,‚Äù said Denison. ‚ÄúI feel so sorry for Goro Miyazaki. He's set up to fail from the very beginning by Suzuki who invites him in to do the work [for 2006's ‚ÄòTales from Earthsea'] and then creates a narrative of discord between Goro and his father.‚Äù

 










Hayao Miyazaki's ubiquity comes with other problematic elements. ‚ÄúWhat Miyazaki means as a buzzword that can now be boiled down to an aesthetic, a vibe, or an AI filter,‚Äù said Leader. ‚ÄúThe real person that is existing right now in Japan isn't the Miyazaki fans know. Instead, Miyazaki is the meme of him saying [of artificial intelligence animation], ‚ÄòIt's an insult to life itself.' It happens with any creator. They get flattened once 1000s around the world are tattooing them onto their body. Steven Spielberg fought for many years against being the guy who makes films where a kid looks up at the sky, or the Scorsese thing where he only makes films about gangsters. Miyazaki has reached that level.‚Äù

‚ÄúI feel like the boy in the Heron is very interesting,‚Äù said Denison. ‚ÄúA lot of people have been commenting about the fact that it's not as original as some of his other films. I think that's because it's that much more personal. This is a master animator looking back over his career, over his relationships, and what people in his life have meant to him, and building a story around that it is just that much more personal for him.‚Äù

Leader points out how Miyazaki's work has evolved since the early '90s. ‚ÄúThe Balkan conflicts with Yugoslavia radicalized him and changed his view of the world. Then, you see that happen again in the early 2000s with the war on terror and post-911 American imperialist stuff in the Middle East. You do see his worldview change through the films. Also in his old age, his films become about him again.‚Äù

 










There have been times when the image Ghibli sells directly conflicts with its actions. ‚ÄúThere are these women behind the scenes that you keep seeing in all these documentaries whose names are never listed, who don't get a lot of credit for the work they do,‚Äù said Denison. ‚ÄúThat was one of the things that drew me to write the book. I wanted to think about how the studio with this stellar reputation for making feminist animated heroines relegates all these women to the backgrounds.

‚ÄúIn the early days of Japanese animation at places like Toei Animation, where Takahata and Miyazaki trained, women weren't allowed to train as directors. It used to be the case that women retired after they got married as an expected part of the industry. It's also the case that women have been at the bottom lines of the industry and been very exploited. The practice of working from home and being paid by the cell is something that applied more to women across the decades.‚Äù

Though Ghibli did a lot of work to improve working conditions, the studio has never promoted a woman to direct a film. ‚Äú'Porco Rosso' is the only movie where women got promoted to big roles,‚Äù added Denison. ‚ÄúEverybody was busy working on ‚ÄòOnly Yesterday,' so Miyazaki's usual team wasn't available to him, and so he looked around the studio and elevated the seven people he felt deserved elevation, and apparently they all just happened to be women.‚Äù

 










The idea of succession and promoting talent has been a stumbling block for Ghibli, putting the future of the studio beyond Takahata, Miyazaki, and Suzuki into doubt. ‚ÄúI don't think without the three of them, there's a reason to keep it going,‚Äù said Denison. ‚ÄúI don't think there's the impetus behind it, but it's also a brand name that Nippon TV [which acquired Ghibli in 2023] bought into so they could use the intellectual properties and extrapolate them and keep the theme parks going. They could import directors like Yonebayashi back in and do new films with new directors, but I don't know if I see that happening.‚Äù

Leader believes that the era of the studio actively making things is over, allowing us to look back on their unique place in the cinematic landscape. ‚ÄúThey were able to create the sense that the studio was having this huge cultural impact, but they weren't a Disney-level operation. Also, other auteurs that we would put Miyazaki alongside, their access to their art is dictated by bigger studios. The Christopher Nolan story is whether he's working with Warner Bros. or Universal, Scorsese has to go to Netflix or Apple to get funding. Ghibli managed to do it in a way that was relatively independent and unsullied of that business. You wouldn't have Miyazaki trying to pitch a Kool-Aid movie.‚Äù

Title: ‚ÄòEddington' Trailer: Ari Aster's Western of Pandemic Paranoia Hits Theaters After Dividing Cannes
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

A24 has dropped the trailer for ‚ÄúEddington,‚Äù Ari Aster‚Äòs modern western that divided the Cannes Film Festival after its Croisette premiere. The film will hit theaters nationwide July 18 ‚Äî and it very well may ‚Äúhit‚Äù with heated debate.

The film takes place in 2020 ‚Äî yes, that 2020 ‚Äî in the most visceral way, with the anti-mask local sheriff (Joaquin Phoenix) of the fictional Eddington, New Mexico, facing off against the town's COVID-guideline-advocate mayor, played by Pedro Pascal (the second of his three summer releases). The heavy-hitter cast also includes Emma Stone, Austin Butler, Luke Grimes, Deirdre O'Connell, Micheal Ward, Am√©lie Hoeferle, Clifton Collins Jr., and William Belleau, all of whom represent various perspectives on the pandemic spectrum.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		




Related Stories Celine Song on Why ‚ÄòMaterialists' Skipping Festivals for Theaters Was the Right Move ‚Äî and the Irresistible Influence of ‚ÄòSex and the City' ‚ÄòToo Much' Trailer: Lena Dunham Directs Her Semi-Autobiographical Series with Megan Stalter and Will Sharpe 

IndieWire reported last month on the film's polarizing audience response, with people truly either loving or hating the film, and few in between. The cast and crew addressed the controversial COVID epic's hot-button reactions at a Cannes press conference.

 










‚ÄúIt's very scary to participate in a movie that speaks to issues like this,‚Äù Pascal said. ‚ÄúIt's far too intimidating a question for me to address. I'm not informed enough. I want people to be safe and protective. I want very much to be on the right side of history ‚Ä¶ I felt like [Aster] wrote something that was all our worst fears as that lockdown experience was already a fracturing society. This was building toward an untethered sense of reality. There is a point of not going back. I was overwhelmed by that fear, and it's wonderful that it was confirmed by Ari.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wrote this movie in a state of fear and anxiety. I wanted to try and pull back and show what it feels like to live in a world where nobody can agree on what is real anymore,‚Äù Aster added at the same presser.

IndieWire's David Ehrlich wrote in his A- review that the director is ‚Äúexclusively interested in making the kind of films that should be reviewed straight onto a prescription pad, is too beholden to his neuroses for his latest movie to play like a cheap provocation. This time, however, there's a good chance those are your neuroses, too.‚Äù

Prior to its release, ‚ÄúEddington‚Äù will open the Fantasia International Film Festival on July 16. It will be in theaters everywhere July 18. Watch the trailer below.

Title: Pedro Almod√≥var's Next Movie ‚ÄòBitter Christmas' Set for Spanish Theaters and Streamer Movistar Plus+
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Pedro Almod√≥var has found his next project. The auteur is now at work on ‚ÄúBitter Christmas‚Äù for Spanish streaming platform Movistar Plus+. Almod√≥var also collaborated with the platform on his English-language feature debut, ‚ÄúThe Room Next Door.‚Äù

‚ÄúBitter Christmas,‚Äù or ‚ÄúAmarga Navidad,‚Äù stars a slew of Almod√≥var newcomers and staples, including B√°rbara Lennie (‚ÄúPetra‚Äù), Leonardo Sbaraglia (‚ÄúPain and Glory‚Äù), Aitana S√°nchez-Gij√≥n (‚ÄúParallel Mothers‚Äù), Victoria Luengo (‚ÄúThe Room Next Door‚Äù), Patrick Criado (‚ÄúRiot Police‚Äù), Milena Smit (‚ÄúParallel Mothers‚Äù), and Quim Guti√©rrez (‚ÄúDarkbluealmostblack‚Äù). The film will be released in Spanish theaters in 2026, with Warner Bros. Pictures Spain distributing. It will then debut exclusively on the Movistar Plus+ platform.

 








Related Stories Studio Ghibli at 40: Can an Ethical Animation Studio Still Exist, or Even Survive? ‚ÄòEddington' Trailer: Ari Aster's Western of Pandemic Paranoia Hits Theaters After Dividing Cannes 

IndieWire has reached out to Almod√≥var's representatives for details about a possible U.S. release, though it can be assumed Sony Pictures Classics will release the film in North America, as it has all of Almod√≥var's recent outings. We're told that festival play and a U.S. release will take place before the Movistar+ premiere.

 










‚ÄúBitter Christmas‚Äù centers on advertising director Elsa, now mourning the loss of her mother over a December holiday weekend. The official synopsis, as shared by Variety, reads: ‚ÄúShe throws herself into work as a form of escape, not realizing she's denying herself the time to grieve. Her relentless pace is interrupted when a panic attack forces her to take a break. Her partner, Bonifacio, becomes her anchor in this moment of crisis. Elsa decides to travel to the island of Lanzarote with her friend Patricia, who is also looking to get away from Madrid, while Bonifacio stays behind in the city. The story of these three characters, and several others, runs parallel to that of screenwriter and film director Ra√∫l Dur√°n, intertwining fiction and reality. ‚ÄòBitter Christmas' explores how life and fiction are inseparably linked, sometimes painfully so.‚Äù

The project is currently filming in Madrid and Lanzarote. Almod√≥var and his brother, Agust√≠n Almod√≥var, produce through their El Deseo banner in collaboration with Movistar Plus+.

Almod√≥var won the 2024 Venice Film Festival Golden Lion for ‚ÄúThe Room Next Door,‚Äù distributed stateside by Sony Pictures Classics. ‚ÄúI was very concerned about the English,‚Äù Almod√≥var told IndieWire about his first film in English. ‚ÄúWe wanted an English that should sound American. My films have never been naturalistic. I have never aspired to the mumbling or babbling or pausing or some of those things that happen in regular language. I like my language to be concentrated and precise. In Spanish, it has worked well.‚Äù
